I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity investment of up to $20 million equivalent in Thunip Water Investment Co., Ltd., an 
investment company to be established in Beijing, the People’s Republic of China (PRC), by 
Thunip  Holdings  Co.,  Ltd.  for  the  Tsinghua  Water  Infrastructure  Development  Project  (the 
Project).1 
 
 
II.  INTRODUCTION 
2.  The Project is being sponsored by Thunip Holdings,2 a leading domestic engineering-
procurement-construction  (EPC)  contractor,  developer,  and  investor  in  the  environmental 
protection sector in the PRC. Although its investment focus is wastewater treatment and water 
supply projects, Thunip Holdings engages in various environmental protection activities, mainly 
in  consultancy,  EPC  and  operation,  and  covers  water  supply,  wastewater  treatment,  soil 
recovery, sanitary landfill, and incineration. Thunip Holdings has been involved in more than 
1,000 environmental protection projects, and its good reputation, solid track record, and awards 
from  the  Government  prove  that  the  company  has  outstanding  technical  capacity  and 
management skills.  
 
3.  The proposed formation of Thunip Water was a response to the increasing opportunities 
for commercial capital and sound management to participate in the PRC water supply and 
wastewater  treatment  sectors.  Thunip  Water,  through  joint  ventures  with  various  partners, 
including the water supply and/or sewage utility companies of various municipalities, will build, 
rehabilitate,  expand,  upgrade,  privatize,  and/or  operate  small  and  medium-scale  water 
infrastructure facilities, with a strong focus on wastewater treatment projects, in various cities in 
the PRC.    
 
 
III.  BACKGROUND 
A.  The Water and Wastewater Sectors 
4.  Reducing the pollution of rivers and lakes and improving the supply of clean drinking 
water  is  part  of  any  pro-poor  development  strategy.  The  poor  are  most  vulnerable  to 
environment-induced diseases and are least capable of paying for adequate medical attention 
for digestive track ailments associated with drinking polluted water. The pollution of rivers and 
lakes  reduces  already  scarce  water  sources  for  drinking  water.  Bottled  water  is  a  very 
expensive alternative to clean, potable tap water. The financial burden of buying bottled water 
falls most heavily on the poor and can account for a disproportionately high portion of their 
limited incomes. Much remains to be done to reduce the adverse impact of water pollution on 
the poor and to end shortages of clean drinking water. 
 
5.  In the PRC, only about 40% of urban wastewater is treated and the rest is discharged 
untreated into rivers, lakes and seas.  More than 40% of the water in the seven major river

on the expertise, track record and strategy of Thunip Holdings and the market situation, it is expected that the main 
focus will be on wastewater treatment projects.

2   
basins  does  not  meet  the  Grade  III3 national  quality  standard.  Major  lakes  have  serious 
eutrophication problems. The Government is aware that addressing environmental problems is 
critical for sustainable development and poverty reduction. It plans to increase centralized urban 
wastewater treatment capacity during the 10th Five-Year Plan period (2001–2005) by 26 million 
m3/day, which will raise the treatment rate of municipal wastewater from 34% to 45%.4 It is 
estimated that CNY110–120 billion is needed to reach this target, including the cost of building 
sewerage networks. Mainly because of a lack of financial resources, progress is behind the 
Government’s schedule.  
 
6.  The pollution of rivers and lakes puts further pressure on already scarce water sources. 
Water resources and availability in the PRC vary significantly across regions and during the 
year, and water scarcity is one of the biggest challenges facing the country. There are serious 
water shortages in northern PRC. Per capita water availability ranges from 360 m3 to 750 m3 
(both of which are lower than the international definition of water scarcity of 1,000 m3/person). 
Although more than 90% of urban households in large cities have access to piped water, this 
figure  obscures  shortages  in  many  cities,  particularly  those  in  the  water-scarce  northern 
provinces.  
 
7.  Increased urbanization has placed pressure on water supply and wastewater treatment 
and has had a negative impact on water quality. Inadequate facilities for treating municipal 
wastewater have led to pollution of already scarce water sources. The urban population in the 
PRC was about 542 million in 2004, and another 150–200 million people from rural areas are 
expected to migrate to cities over the next 10–15 years. More investment is needed to supply 
clean drinking water and to treat wastewater. The Ministry of Construction has estimated the 
investment needs for water infrastructure during 2000–2010 to be at least CNY530 billion ($65 
billion).  
 
8.  The  responsibility  for  developing  water  infrastructure  falls  on  local  municipalities. 
However, funding for water infrastructure in municipalities is limited, mainly because (i) they are 
constrained by their limited financial budgets and overall infrastructure needs, (ii) they do not 
have  direct  access  to  multilateral  or  other  external  financing  sources,  and  (iii)  some 
municipalities may not be able to meet the Government’s counterpart funding requirements.  
 
9.  Private  sector  funding  is  clearly  needed  for  both  the  water  supply  and  wastewater 
treatment sectors. Private sector participation can also lead to more use of new technology and 
enhance  efficiency.  However,  although  the  Government  has  encouraged  private  sector 
participation, private funding in water and sanitation infrastructure is negligible in wastewater 
treatment. This lack of interest is due to (i) complicated and rigid project approval procedures, (ii) 
inconsistent application of government regulations, (iii) inadequate tariff revenue, and (iv) high 
transaction and operating costs.   
 
10.  Difficulty in raising financing is another significant barrier to private sector participation. 
Water infrastructure projects, especially wastewater treatment facilities, tend to be small, so 
there  are  relatively  high  transaction  costs  in  setting  up  complicated  funding  structures. 
Traditional funding structures usually require a high proportion of equity investment and/or 
recourse to a strong parent company. Experienced international investors are interested only in

3
large projects with sophisticated funding structures, and have little interest in small projects. 
Local investors, on the other hand, are relatively new and have limited financial resources, so 
they can develop only a few projects. Limited private sector participation in the water and 
wastewater sectors of PRC, especially in small and medium-scale projects, has restricted the 
mobilization of resources for the sector.  In the  development of water infrastructure in the PRC, 
priority needs to be given to dedicated and qualified local sponsors through equity investments, 
in order to mobilize debt financing in the domestic loan market, which is relatively liquid.  
 
B.  Government Policies and Plans 
11.  The  Government  has  accorded  priority  in  the  10th  Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005)  to 
resolving water pollution and the scarcity of water, especially in urban areas, as the Government 
plans to develop small- and medium-sized cities to absorb surplus rural labor. According to the 
State Environment Protection Administration (SEPA) this will be continued in 11th Five Year 
Plan (2006–2010). The Government’s strategy in the water sector focuses on (i) developing 
water sources; (ii) protecting existing sources by controlling industrial and residential pollution; 
(iii) controlling  overextraction  from  groundwater  resources;  (iv)  introducing  water-efficient 
technologies  and  operations;  and  (v)  using  appropriate  pricing  mechanisms  to  encourage 
conservation and generate funds for operation, maintenance, and investment. To complement 
increased  investments  in  urban  water  supply  and  wastewater  treatment  facilities,  the 
Government will continue to encourage and support raising water and wastewater tariffs to 
commercial levels, which will improve financial management for water and wastewater projects, 
and encourage private sector participation. 
 
C.  ADB’s Experience and Strategy in Water and Wastewater Sectors 
12.  ADB is active in the water supply and wastewater treatment sectors in the PRC. Its work 
with  the  Government  helps  to  improve  living  standards  and  economic  productivity,  reduce 
environmental degradation, and promote sustainable development. ADB lending to the water 
supply and wastewater treatment sectors started in 1993, and, as of October 2005, 13 loans 
totaling $1.3 billion for water supply and sanitation projects, largely in the urban areas, had been 
approved.  These  loans  have  financed  about  4  million  m3/day  of  capacity  to  supply  clean 
drinking water and more than 2 million m3/day of wastewater treatment. ADB is financing urban 
wastewater, sewage treatment, water supply, and water resources management projects in line 
with its strategy to support environmental improvement in the PRC. To maximize development 
impact, especially among the urban poor, ADB's involvement has been targeted at densely 
populated urban areas.  
 
13.  The principal objectives of ADB assistance in the sector are to (i) address environmental 
issues in the water sector, (ii) provide safe drinking water and sanitation facilities to improve the 
health  and  productivity  of  large  urban  populations,  (iii)  improve  financial  management  to 
generate internal resources for investment and ensure sustainable operations and maintenance, 
and (iv) improve institutional capacity to operate and maintain urban systems effectively. These 
objectives are in line with ADB’s water policy.5  
 
                                                 
5  ADB. 2001. Water For All. Manila.

4   
D.  Country Strategy and Private Sector Operations in the PRC 
14.  The ADB country strategy and program for the PRC6 is based on four development 
objectives:  (i)  promoting  equitable  and  inclusive  growth,  (ii)  making  markets  work  better, 
(iii) improving  the  environment,  and  (iv)  promoting  regional  cooperation.  ADB’s  assistance 
focuses on reducing the inequality between the coastal and interior provinces and the income 
gap  between  the  urban  and  rural  populations.  The  Government  accords  high  priority  to 
expediting the PRC’s transition to a market economy as the basis for growth and job creation, 
which will require more efficient markets for the private sector. This includes tariff reform and the 
conversion of public utility enterprises to private corporations. The Government and ADB also 
promote improvements to the urban environment. It is anticipated that ADB's public sector 
operations in the PRC will support 6–7 urban wastewater management projects in 2006–2008. 
 
15.  ADB’s private sector operations in the PRC focus on the infrastructure and energy 
sectors, the financial sector, and environmental improvements.   
 
16.  ADB has played a particularly significant role in promoting private sector involvement in 
the PRC’s water sector. In 1996, ADB technical assistance promoted private sector involvement 
on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis for water supply projects.7  This was followed by further 
technical assistance to help the Government prepare a pilot BOT project8 which resulted in the 
successful preparation  and  implementation  of  the  Chengdu  Water  Supply  Project,9 now  in 
commercial operation.   
 
17.  ADB plans to increase its private sector operations in the PRC substantially and has 
recently raised local currency resources through its first CNY-denominated bond issue. The 
Tsinghua Water Infrastructure Development Project will be ADB’s first infrastructure project 
using local currency in the PRC, which is in line with ADB’s strategy of using local currency and 
therefore  avoiding  foreign  exchange  risk.  In  the  infrastructure  and  energy  sectors,  ADB 
prioritizes pioneering projects with innovative contractual and financial structuring to encourage 
private  sector  participation,  enhance  management  expertise,  and  improve  corporate 
governance. ADB promotes commercialization, privatization, and public–private partnerships 
through technology and management transfer to local entities currently owned by the public 
sector.  
 
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Description 
18.  The Project is designed to attract equity funds to finance the development of municipal 
water and wastewater infrastructure facilities, with a strong focus on wastewater treatment. It 
will consist of the initial equity commitments for the capitalization of Thunip Water, totaling up to 
$100 million: 40% from the Thunip Holdings and 60% from commitments by ADB and other 
private investors. Thunip Water will enter into joint ventures with various partners, including the

5
water supply and/or sewage utility companies of various municipalities, to build, rehabilitate, 
expand,  upgrade,  privatize,  and/or  operate  small  and  medium-scale  water  infrastructure 
facilities, including water supply and wastewater treatment projects, in various cities in the PRC. 
After the committed funds in the Project are fully deployed, it is anticipated that Thunip Water 
will continue its operations, retaining earnings, and raising funds from other sources   
 
19.  Thunip Water will target cities for its water supply and wastewater treatment projects. 
Most of its investment will be green field projects under the BOT scheme or other similar 
structures.  In smaller cities, the form of investment will be tailored to suit the specific local 
situation. Some projects may involve Thunip Water purchasing an existing water or wastewater 
treatment plant for refurbishing and/or expanding, and the municipality using the sales proceeds 
to expand the local distribution or sewerage network, add raw water supply capacity, and/or to 
develop other water and wastewater infrastructures. Thunip Water is expected to develop 20–30 
new projects within the next 5 years, building an investment portfolio of $100 million. Thunip 
Water will use the cash receipts from dividends from its joint ventures to develop new projects 
and service its obligations to the investors, including ADB. Through investments successfully 
negotiated  with  partner  municipalities,  Thunip  Water  may  also  obtain  priority  position  for 
participation in future expansion of the facilities involved.  
 
B.  Sponsor 
20.  Incorporated  in  Beijing  in  2002,  Thunip  Holdings  originated  from  an  environmental 
engineering  centre  (established  in  1988)  of  Tsinghua  University,  a  well-known  national 
university and has outstanding technical capacity. Since its launch, Thunip Holdings has been 
supported by Tsinghua University and university-owned companies with respect to technology, 
human resource and business opportunity. Thunip Holdings is run on a commercial basis and 
enjoys autonomy and managerial freedom.     
 
21.  Thunip Holdings has considerable experience of developing and operating wastewater 
treatment  projects  in  the  PRC.    It  has  strong  technology  and  research  capability,  and  its 
operational experience is satisfactory.  Because of its established market reputation and 17 
years’ experience in environmental protection, it is often approached by municipalities seeking 
assistance on water and wastewater projects. This helps it to minimize its marketing efforts. 
With  low  administration  and  marketing  expenses,  Thunip  Holdings  is  able  to  focus  on 
developing small and medium-scale water and wastewater facilities to a high standard.   
 
C.  Environmental Aspects and Social Dimensions 
1.  Environmental Aspects 
22.  The Project will have positive environmental impacts on clean drinking water supply and 
water pollution control in small and medium-sized municipalities. It will also help the government 
to diversify financial sources for environmental investment and enhance its effectiveness. The 
Project will have limited and short-term adverse environmental impacts and mitigation measures 
will be taken during construction. Treatment plant sites are usually located outside city limits on 
vacant plots or in sparsely populated areas, which limits their impact. During treatment plant 
operations, noise and odor pollution may be created, so plant designs will include noise and 
odor control facilities and equipment. Treatment plant sites will incorporate landscape designs. 
 
23.  The Project is classified as environmental category FI. Thunip Water will set up an 
environmental management system (EMS), including environmental assessment and review

6   
procedures  for  potential  investments  that  are  acceptable  to  ADB.  ADB’s  environmental 
guidelines and policies and the PRC’s environmental laws and regulations will be complied with, 
and implementation of environmental mitigation measures will be monitored in collaboration with 
municipal environmental protection bureaus. Such environmental mitigation measures will be 
included in progress reports on project implementation and annual reports on environmental 
monitoring. Thunip Water will confirm to ADB periodically its compliance with ADB and PRC 
environmental requirements and make reports on these matters available to ADB. A conceptual 
framework for the establishment of an EMS for the Thunip Water is given in Appendix 2. 
 
2.  Social Dimensions 
24.  The Project is classified as involuntary resettlement category FI and indigenous people 
category  C.  Under  the  current  private  sector  participation  arrangements  for  water  and 
wastewater projects in the PRC, land acquisition and relocation of inhabitants are carried out by 
the municipal governments before the concessions are open for competition. Thunip Water will 
therefore have only a limited role in land acquisition and relocation. Before investing, Thunip 
Water will undertake due diligence to ensure that any water or wastewater project has not, or 
will not, involve acquisition of rights to land or displacement of people or enterprises.  In the 
event that Thunip Water and/or any of the joint venture projects becomes involved in the 
acquisition  of  ownership  or  possession  of  land  use  rights,  and  such  acquisition  results  in 
involuntary resettlement, Thunip Water, together with the relevant joint venture, shall ensure 
that  all  acquisition  and  resettlement  activities  are  undertaken  in  accordance  with  the 
requirements of ADB’s policy on involuntary resettlement10 and Thunip Water’s resettlement 
policy framework and resettlement procedural guidelines, as agreed by Thunip Holdings and 
acceptable to ADB (Appendix 3).  Thunip Water, together with its joint venture projects, shall 
ensure compliance with ADB’s policy on indigenous peoples. To ensure tariff affordability, the 
joint venture project selection criteria will include an assessment of tariff affordability.  
 
3.  Development Impacts 
25.  The Project will develop wastewater treatment facilities in the PRC. Over one third of the 
country’s river systems are estimated to be polluted and more than 90% of the catchment areas 
around the cities are badly contaminated. About 50% of water resources do not conform to PRC 
drinking water standards. Investments in wastewater treatment will improve the environment 
and help arrest pollution of water sources, facilitating delivery of water that meets national 
standards and reducing threats to public health. The poor tend to suffer the most economically 
from increased medical costs or loss of income as a result of waterborne diseases. Investments 
in wastewater will reduce these costs and contribute to improving the economy as a whole.  
 
26.  The Project may also expand water supply capacity in the PRC. Access to water has 
been a major problem in some municipalities, particularly in northern PRC. An increase in the 
water supply will enable increased industrial output, among other benefits. Access to piped 
water supply increases productivity by eliminating time spent in fetching and queuing for water 
which can now be channeled to other productive activities. For the urban poor, access to safe 
drinking water reduces the risk of waterborne diseases, improving health and productivity.  
 
 
 
                                                 
10  ADB. 1995. Involuntary Resettlement. Manila.

7
4.  Development Effectiveness 
a.  Project Performance 
 
27.  The Project will be assessed against its specific investment capital, operational, and 
financial objectives. Effectiveness will be measured by how successfully the Project attracts 
private sector capital, how it secures municipal water and wastewater facility concessions, 
whether it develops and expands municipal water and wastewater infrastructure facilities, how 
much water it supplies, how much wastewater it treats, and whether it improves the quality of 
urban life and public health. The Project will also be judged by its financial profitability, its 
sustainability, and timely returns to investors. 
   
  b.   Economic Sustainability 
 
28.  From an economic sustainability point of view, the Project will be assessed on its ability 
to develop and implement water infrastructure facilities, supply water to and treat wastewater 
from consumers, and contribute to environment improvements and economic growth. Additional 
employment created as a result of project implementation will also be taken into account.  
   
  c.   Private Sector Development 
 
29.  The Project will be assessed on how it contributes to private sector development. The 
focus will be on its commercial and financial viability, and on its catalytic effect on future private 
investments in the water and wastewater sectors and on the broader economy.  
 
D.  Financing Plan 
30.  Thunip Holdings plans to raise up to $60 million equity, in US dollars and/or yuan, from 
strategic investors, including ADB, to fund its planned investments in the water and wastewater 
sectors over the next 5 years. The funding needs of Thunip Water will largely depend on the 
equity requirements of its new joint venture projects and ADB’s investment will be used in these 
new  joint  venture  projects.  The  joint  venture  projects  will  be  able  to  borrow  from  local 
commercial banks.  
 
E.  Other Potential Investors 
31.  Thunip Holdings is aiming to raise $60 million from a select group of investors (including 
ADB) in a private placement. Commitments from a substantial portion of the private placement 
will be a condition for ADB’s equity disbursement.   
 
 
V.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Proposed Equity Investment 
32.  The proposed ADB investment will be up to $20 million equivalent, in US dollars or 
yuan,11 to be disbursed in stages, for a stake of up to 20% of the equity capital of Thunip Water. 
                                                 
11  The proposed ADB investment will preferably be disbursed in yuan. However, although the Government has given 
general  approval  for  ADB  to  use  of  the  proceeds  of  ADB’s  CNY-denominated  bonds  to  undertake  equity 
investment, if ADB is to use the bond proceeds for equity investment in an investment company the Government’s

8   
Through Thunip Water, the ADB funds will be invested in new water supply and wastewater 
treatment projects. It is expected that the new projects will be developed over the next 5 years, 
so the proposed ADB investment will be available for disbursement for 5 years, based on the 
investment requirements of Thunip Water. ADB’s shareholding in Thunip Water will be no more 
than 20% at any point of time. 
 
B.  Justification 
33.  ADB’s support for the Project is justified because it will have significant development 
impacts and demonstration effects; it complements the Government’s development plans and 
ADB’s operational strategies; and ADB’s participation in the Project will add value.  
 
(i)  By developing small or medium-scale wastewater treatment and water supply 
facilities across the PRC, thus helping to reduce pollution of water sources and 
improving  the  quantity  and  quality  of  water,  the  Project  will  support  the 
Government’s  11th  Five-Year  Plan,  and  contribute  to  the  achievement  of 
Government targets for urban sewage treatment and water supply. 
 
(ii)  The Project is consistent with ADB’s country, sector and thematic strategies and 
its involvement in the water supply and wastewater treatment sectors in the 
PRC.12 Lessons learned will be conveyed to the Government.   
 
(iii)  The  expansion  of  small  and  medium-scale  municipal  water  and  wastewater 
infrastructure facilities will improve the quality of urban life and public health, 
arrest environmental degradation, and sustain acceptable levels of economic 
growth. Municipalities to be covered by the Project, including those in the interior 
provinces, will benefit from foreign capital assistance, technology transfer, and 
managerial expertise. 
 
(iv)  ADB’s proposed investment will sponsor the establishment of Thunip Water, and 
add  value  by  promoting  best  commercial  practices  and  good  corporate 
governance,  as  well  as  compliance  with  ADB’s  environmental  and  social 
guidelines. Thunip Water will be a sustainable concern and will operate beyond 
the life of the ADB investment. ADB has been extensively involved in structuring 
the Project.  
 
(v)  ADB has taken a lead role in mobilizing the remainder of the private placement. 
ADB’s role in the project is truly catalytic for (a) mobilizing additional equity 
investment in Thunip Water by raising confidence through its planned investment 
and (b) satisfying the equity requirements for debt financing of joint ventures in 
the local financial market. 
 
(vi)  The Project aims to address the key financial constraints in developing municipal 
water and wastewater infrastructure facilities. It will enable ADB to extend its 
private  sector  operations  to  small  and  medium-scale  water  and  wastewater 
infrastructure projects. ADB will benefit from the experience and expertise of an

VI.  ASSURANCES 
34.  A framework agreement relating to ADB’s status, privileges, and immunities with respect 
to its equity investments and lending operations in the private sector is in effect between the 
Government and ADB. Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development 
Bank, the Government will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed 
assistance to the Project. No funding will be disbursed until ADB receives such confirmation. In 
addition, ADB will enter into suitable subscription and shareholders’ agreement on terms and 
conditions satisfactory to ADB.   
 
 
VII.  RECOMMENDATION 
35.  I am satisfied that the proposed investment would comply with the Articles of Agreement 
of ADB and, acting in the absence of the President, under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the 
Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board approve the proposed investment of 
up to $20 million, to be disbursed in US dollars or yuan, in an equity stake in Thunip Water 
Investment Co., Ltd. on terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.

CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL 
MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR THUNIP WATER INVESTMENT COMPANY LIMITED 
A.  Introduction   
 
1.  As a holding company for environmental management, Thunip Water Investment Co., 
Ltd. (Thunip Water) is committed to ensuring that its water and wastewater treatment business 
will not create adverse environmental and social impacts. In this regard, Thunip Water will need 
to establish and effectively operate an appropriate environmental management system (EMS) at 
both the corporate and joint venture company levels.  This appendix presents a conceptual 
framework for the establishment of EMS in the context of Thunip Water. It is intended to serve 
as a basis for discussion between the ADB and Thunip Water to work out an appropriate EMS 
acceptable to both parties.  
 
2.  The conceptual framework presented herein is based on a good understanding of: (i) the 
extent to which Thunip Water can manage environmental and social aspects of its business; 
and (ii) environmental and social impacts of water and wastewater treatment projects.  
 
B.  Environmental Policy Framework 
 
3.  Thunip Water needs to formulate a pragmatic corporate policy for environmental and 
social  management  of  its  business.  The  EMS  is  a  tool  to  ensure  that  the  corporate 
environmental and social policy will be efficiently and effectively implemented by all its business 
units  and  joint  venture  companies.  This  section  proposes  a  policy  statement  and  guiding 
principles for implementing the policy as part of the normal conduct of the business.  
 
1.  Suggested Policy Statement 
 
4.  An environmental policy should 
 
(i)  be relevant to activities, 
 
(ii)  comply with relevant environmental legislation and standards, 
 
(iii)  commit to the prevention of pollution, 
 
(iv)  commit to continual improvement, 
 
(v)  commit to setting environmental objectives and targets, 
 
(vi)  be known to employees and public, and 
 
(vii)  encourage  cleaner  production  mechanism  during  design  and  operation  of 
facilities. 
 
5.  Based  on  the  above  principles,  the  following  policy  statement  for  Thunip  Water  is 
suggested: 
 
  Our core business is environmental improvement through providing water and 
wastewater treatment services in various cities in the People’s Republic of China.

Appendix 2   13
As a good corporate citizen, we are fully committed to minimizing environmental 
and social impacts of our water and wastewater treatment plant construction and 
operations, in full compliance with all relevant national and local laws, regulations 
and standards regarding environmental and social aspects of our business.  We 
will strive to excel in this endeavor with full involvement of our staff and the 
public. 
 
6.  Thunip  Water  should  revise  the  above  suggested  policy  statement  as  it  sees 
appropriate. However, the policy should follow the above principles. 
 
2.  Guiding Principles for Policy Implementation 
 
7.  The following guiding principles are suggested for implementation of Thunip Water’s 
environmental and social policy: 
 
(i)  Guiding Principles for Thunip Water 
 
(a)  Thunip Water will avoid participating in bidding for projects that will be 
constructed on intensively inhabited land or on ecologically or socially 
sensitive areas. Examples of such sensitive areas include cultural sites 
and swamp forests. 
 
(b)  Thunip Water will ensure that the land provided by the local governments 
has no pending issues with the former occupants related to compensation 
and resettlement assistance. 
 
(c)  Thunip Water will review the project environmental impact assessment 
(EIA)  and  the  recommended  environmental  management  plan  (EMP) 
prepared by the local governments to identify gaps or inadequacies that 
could undermine the environmental and social integrity of the project. If 
such inadequacies are found, Thunip Water will discuss with the local 
governments how the EIA and EMP can be improved. 
 
(d)  Thunip Water will review the detailed designs and specifications prepared 
by the engaged design institutes or firms, to ensure that the designs and 
specifications are environmentally sound and fully comply with the EMP. 
 
(e)  Thunip  Water  will  include  in  the  construction  contracts  appropriate 
environmental and social management clauses related to the EMP, and 
will ensure that the contractors will fully comply with the environmental 
and social management clauses and applicable rules and regulations of 
the national and local governments.  
 
(f)  Thunip  Water  will  fully  comply  with  the  monitoring  and  reporting 
requirements during construction as prescribed in the EMP in compliance 
with applicable national and local laws and regulations. 
 
(g)  Thunip  Water  will  fully  comply  with  the  monitoring  and  reporting 
requirements during the operation of project facilities as prescribed in the 
EMP  in  compliance  with  applicable  national  and  local  laws  and 
regulations.

(h)  Thunip  Water  will  report  its  environmental  and  social  management 
activities as part of its annual reports. 
 
(ii)  Guiding Principles for the joint venture companies 
 
(a)  Each joint venture company will establish an appropriate EMS to ensure 
full integration of environmental and social management with its routine 
operation and maintenance of water and wastewater treatment plants and 
associated facilities.   
 
(b)  Each joint venture company will efficiently operate water and wastewater 
treatment plants including environmental management facilities to ensure 
full  compliance  with  the  applicable  national  and  local  laws  and 
regulations, and efficient use of energy and water resources. 
 
(c)  Each joint venture company will prepare an emergency response plan 
(ERP) specific to its operations. 
 
(d)  Each  joint  venture  company  will  implement  an  appropriate  public 
information program related to its environmental and social management 
activities. 
 
(e)  Each joint venture company is encouraged to be part of the community in 
which it operates. 
 
C.  Environmental Management System (EMS) Design Framework 
 
1.  EMS Elements and Activities 
 
8.  The EMS elements will be in line with the four main tasks of management “plan, do, 
check, act.” These elements involve different activities during the construction and operation 
stages  of  a  project.  Activities  at  the  corporate  and  joint  venture  company  levels  are  also 
different. The activities at the corporate level are focused on overseeing the environmental and 
social management activities carried out at the joint venture company level.  
 
2.  Work Process and Procedures 
 
9.  In setting up the EMS, Thunip Water will have to establish clear work processes and 
procedures or guidelines for all tasks at the corporate and subsidiary company levels, including:   
   
(i)  Thunip Water Level 
 
(a)  Review of EIA, EMP and detailed design prepared by the engaged design 
institutes or firms and approved by the local governments as necessary 
 
(b)  Changes or modifications of EMP and detailed designs 
 
(c)  Review of environmental and social management plan of the contractors’ 
proposals

clauses in the construction contracts 
 
(e)  Audit of environmental and social management compliance during the

(f)  Reporting the corporate environmental and social performance 
 
(ii)  Joint Venture Company Level 
 
(a)  Monitoring and evaluation of contractor’s compliance with environmental

(b)  Preparation of environmental and social management plan as part of its

(d)  Reporting the company environmental and social performance 
  
3.  Organization 
 
a.  Thunip Water Level 
 
10.  Thunip  Water  should  have  one  designated  manager  for  environmental  and  social 
management to operate the EMS. The environmental and social (ES) manager may have one 
professional assistant if the workload warrants. The ES manager should report directly to the 
Managing Director. It would be appropriate to include safety aspects of the treatment plant 
operations in the EMS. 
 
b.  Joint Venture Level 
 
11.  At the treatment plant level, the environmental and social management activities are 
carried out as part of routine plant operations. For example, the operation and maintenance of 
odor control equipment and facilities are normally a part of the operation and control of the 
wastewater treatment plant. However, the results of environmental and social management 
should  be  reviewed  and  evaluated  separately  from  those  of  the  normal  treatment  plant 
operations.   
 
12.  The  organization  for  EMS  operation  at  the  company  level  should  be  simple.  It  is 
proposed that a deputy general manager or assistant general manager concurrently serves as 
environmental and social manager. His/her main tasks will be monitoring and evaluation of the 
environmental and social performance of the company, rectifying compliance deficiencies, and 
reporting to the general manager.  
 
4.  Budgeting 
 
13.  Expenses incurred in environmental and social management at the treatment plant level 
will  be  included  in  the  budget  for  operation  of  the  treatment  plant.  Expenses  incurred  in

LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK FOR THUNIP WATER 
INVESTMENT CO., LTD. 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
1.  This resettlement framework defines the policies, procedures, roles and responsibilities 
of  Thunip  Water  Investment  Co.  Ltd.  (Thunip  Water)  for  screening  and  management  of 
involuntary  resettlement  in  projects  undertaken  through  joint  venture  companies.    The 
resettlement framework has been prepared by Thunip Water as part of its commitment to 
complying with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) safeguard policies, in particular ADB’s 
Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995).  
 
B.  Expected Scope of Involuntary Resettlement in Thunip Water Operations 
 
2.  Thunip Water is a holding company that will form joint venture companies, with various 
partners, to undertake some or all of the following activities: finance, design, construct and/or 
operate water and wastewater projects. The holding company expects to invest in 20-30 such 
projects  in  various  locations  around  the  PRC.  Some  projects,  such  as  those  that  involve 
refinancing, upgrading or operation of long-established facilities will not involve involuntary 
resettlement impacts.  Other projects may involve involuntary resettlement impacts through (i) 
land acquisition to expand or construct new facilities; or, (ii) land that has been acquired prior to 
Thunip Water’s involvement.  
 
3.  Thunip Water, itself, will not be involved directly in land acquisition or resettlement. Such 
activities  will  typically  be  undertaken  by  county  or  municipal  governments,  where  Thunip 
Water’s joint venture companies are located. Accordingly, this resettlement framework sets out 
the  procedures  roles  and  responsibilities  for  ensuring  that  ADB’s  involuntary  resettlement 
safeguard requirements are fully complied with by Thunip Water and its joint venture partners. 
 
C.  Investment Selection Criteria 
 
4.  Since water and wastewater investments have a long planning period, preference will be 
given to selecting projects for investment that are at an advanced stage of planning, and where 
municipal  support  and  solid  preparation  are  demonstrated.  Thunip  Water  will  thus  select 
projects  that  conform  with  municipal  land  use  planning  regulations,  evidenced  through 
production of a valid land transfer contract with the relevant municipal land bureau or private title 
holder, together with a valid land title certificate (with red line site map). In addition, Thunip 
Water will ensure that no project is selected for investment that is not in compliance with ADB’s 
Indigenous Peoples Policy (1998). 
 
D.  Definitions 
 
5.  For the purposes of this framework, the following definitions will apply: 
 
(i)  Involuntary  resettlement—refers  to  social  and  economic  impacts  that  are 
permanent or temporary and are caused (a) by acquisition of land and other fixed 
assets, (b) by change in the use of land, or (c) by restrictions imposed on land as 
a result of a Thunip Water investment.   
 
(ii)  Affected person—-includes any people, households, firms, or private institutions 
who,  on  account  of  changes  that result  from  the  project,  will  have  their  (a)

18      Appendix 3 
standard of living adversely affected; (b) right, title, or interest in any house, land 
(including residential, commercial, agricultural, forest, and/or grazing land), water 
resources,  or  any  other  moveable  or  fixed  assets  acquired,  possessed, 
restricted,  or  otherwise  adversely  affected,  in  full  or  in  part,  permanently  or 
temporarily;  and/or  (c)  business,  occupation,  place  of  work  or  residence,  or 
habitat adversely affected, with or without displacement.  
 
E.  Policy Framework 
 
5.  Thunip Water shall ensure that the involuntary resettlement activities of any joint venture 
companies are conducted in accordance with the following: 
 
(i)  ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995); and 
 
(ii)  applicable  national  and  provincial  laws  and  regulations  governing  land 
acquisition, compensation and resettlement, and consultation and disclosure of 
resettlement information.  
 
6.  Objectives for managing involuntary resettlement impacts are  
 
(i)  to avoid involuntary resettlement wherever feasible;  
 
(ii)  to minimize resettlement where population displacement is unavoidable; and 
 
(iii)  to ensure that affected persons receive assistance so that they will be at least as 
well off as they would have been in the absence of the project.  
 
7.  Resettlement plans will pay particular attention to addressing the needs of the poorest 
affected people and vulnerable groups that may be at high risk of impoverishment. 
 
8.  Resettlement plans will stipulate eligibility and entitlement provisions for land losses, 
house losses, crop losses, and loss of other assets at replacement rates. Land losses will be 
compensated as follows: (i) people losing agricultural and residential land will be compensated 
through “land for land" arrangements wherever feasible; (ii) if "land for land" arrangements are 
not  feasible,  the  person  losing  agricultural  land  will  be  reclassified  and  provided  with  job 
opportunities; (iii) cash compensation for lost land will be paid at the rates stipulated by the Land 
Law, 1998, to the villages, which in turn will use the funds received for infrastructure and 
services directly benefiting the affected communities. Resettlement subsidies for land acquired 
will be directly paid to the people affected in cash through the village offices. House losses and 
loss  of  other  structures  will  be  directly  compensated  in  cash  at  replacement  cost  free  of 
demolition  costs  and  salvaged  materials.  In-ground  annual  crop  losses  will  be  directly 
compensated  in  cash  at  current  market  prices.  Business  losses,  including  transfer  and 
downtime costs, will be paid directly to the business owners. Vulnerable households will receive 
assistance for house relocation and reconstruction, to be organized by the relevant village or 
township committee.   
 
F.  Screening for Involuntary Resettlement Impacts 
 
9.  As part of the due diligence process, prior to investing in any joint venture company, 
Thunip Water’s senior officer responsible for social and resettlement performance will determine 
whether any projects to be undertaken through the prospective joint venture company have (i)

historically involved land acquisition or involuntary resettlement; or, (ii) or may in future involve 
involuntary resettlement.  
 
  1.  Joint venture Projects with No Involuntary Resettlement Impact 
 
10.  Where no involuntary resettlement impacts are indicated, no further action with regard to 
this resettlement framework will be required. 
 
  2.  Joint venture Projects with Historical Involuntary Resettlement Impacts 
 
11.  In  case  of  land  acquisition  or  involuntary  resettlement 1  prior  to  Thunip  Water’s 
involvement, Thunip Water’s senior officer responsible for social and resettlement performance 
will cause to have prepared a resettlement due diligence report. The resettlement due diligence 
report should provide (i) a brief history of site land acquisition and resettlement, and parties 
responsible  for  implementation;  (ii)  details  of  affected  land,  population  and  assets; 
(iii) assessment of outcomes with respect to restoration of standards of living and livelihood; 
(iv) information on any outstanding resettlement grievances or related areas of reputational risk; 
and,  (v)  recommend  whether  a  resettlement  plan  is  required  to  define  actions  to  achieve 
compliance with ADB’s resettlement requirements. The resettlement due diligence report should 
be submitted to ADB for review and approval prior to finalizing any joint venture agreement. 
 
  3.  Projects with Planned Involuntary Resettlement 
 
12.  In the event that a joint venture project may involve involuntary resettlement, Thunip 
Water’s senior officer responsible for social and resettlement performance will: 
 
(i)  Prior to investment: 
 
(a)  assess the magnitude of resettlement, and in consultation with ADB, determine 
whether a short or full resettlement plan is required; 
 
(b)  provide the prospective joint venture partner with copies of the ADB policies and 
guidelines; 
 
(c)  advise the prospective joint venture partner of the need for a resettlement plan; 
 
(d)  ensure  that  resettlement  information  is  disclosed  to  affected  persons  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  safeguard  requirements  and  PRC’s  State  Council 
Decision on Deepening Reform of Land Administration (28th Decree of State 
Council of 21 October 2004); 
 
(e)  once a draft resettlement plan has been completed, submit it to ADB for review 
and approval; 
 
(f)  oversight any revisions required by ADB in order to finalize the resettlement plan; 
 
(g)  obtain the joint venture partners’ endorsement of the resettlement plan;

(h)  verify local disclosure of the final resettlement plan; 
 
(i)  submit the final resettlement plan for website disclosure and ADB approval; 
 
(j)  confirm ADB approval before proceeding with investment. 
 
(ii)  Following investment: 
 
(a)  monitor implementation of the resettlement plan;

G.  Resettlement Plans 
 
13.  Prospective joint venture companies involved in or planning involuntary resettlement will 
prepare  a  short  or  full  resettlement  plan,  dependent  on  the  magnitude  and  complexity  of 
resettlement.    A  full  resettlement  plan  will  be  required  where  resettlement  is  ‘significant’.  
Involuntary resettlement is ‘significant’ when 200 or more people will experience major impacts, 
which are defined as: (i) being physically displaced from housing; or, (ii) losing 10% or more of 
their productive assets (income generating). The scope of short and full resettlement plans is 
outlined in Table A3.1 and Table A3.2. 
 
H.  Institutional Responsibilities       
       
15.  Thunip  Water  has  overall  coordination,  planning,  implementation,  and  financing 
responsibilities.  Local  municipal  governments,  through  their  resettlement  offices,  will  be 
responsible for preparation and implementation of the agreed resettlement plans, including 
assets  valuation,  consultation,  and  delivery  of  entitlements.  The  relevant  municipal  land 
management bureaus are responsible for land recording and acquisition approvals. Field tasks 
such as payment of entitlements, replacement land selection, provision of livelihood support, 
and monitoring will be responsibility of township officers. 
 
16.  Thunip Water, together with its joint venture partners and local municipal government, 
will ensure that the relevant municipal land management and resettlement offices are briefed on 
their obligations with respect to ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy and requirements of this 
Resettlement Framework. Thunip Water will provide assurance to ADB that payments are made 
directly and on time to affected persons, and that any shortfalls required to meet resettlement 
objectives are covered. The entitlements will be provided to the people affected before ground 
leveling and demolition commence. Income support will be provided for the period of dislocation. 
 
17.  Thunip  Water  shall  ensure  that  the  requirement  to  comply  with  this  Resettlement 
Framework and ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Plan (1995) shall be incorporated into the 
articles of association of each joint venture company that it invests in. 
 
I.  Disclosure, Consultation, and Grievance Redress 
 
18.  Each resettlement plan will be prepared and implemented in close consultation with 
those affected, and involve surveys and village meetings. Plans in the Chinese language will be 
made available to the public through postings in public places, such as township offices, for

reasonable periods of at least 4 months prior to actual land acquisition. ADB will review and 
approve the resettlement plans, as they are prepared, and once finalized will disclose them on 
its website. Complaints and grievance procedures acceptable to ADB will be established in each 
resettlement plan.  
 
J.  Reporting, Monitoring, and Evaluation 
 
19.  Thunip Water will nominate a senior officer to be responsible for social and resettlement 
performance,  who  has  the  responsibility  to  submit  six  monthly  reports  on  the  forthcoming 
investment pipeline, describing the likelihood of land acquisition and resettlement effects, and 
any minority or labor issues. ADB will review the pipeline reports and may comment on the 
screening requirements and documentation assumptions. Thunip Water will submit an annual 
report  of  performance  monitoring  against  safeguard  policies,  and  upon  and  after  project 
completion.  
 
K.  Capacity and Implementing Arrangements 
 
20.  The senior officer to be responsible for social and resettlement performance will receive 
training in (i) screening of prospective joint venture projects for involuntary resettlement impacts; 
(ii) ADB’s involuntary resettlement procedures and requirements; (iii) resettlement monitoring; 
and, (iv) reporting.  Where warranted, dependent on the scale of resettlement and the capacity 
of  the  prospective  joint  venture  company,  Thunip  Water  may  engage  an  experienced 
resettlement  consultant  to  assist  with  resettlement  planning,  documentation  and 
implementation.

strategy  •  Income restoration strategy with options to restore all types of livelihoods.  
•  Job creation plan, including provisions for income substitution, retraining, 
self-employment and pensions, where required 
•  Business relocation and restoration plan, including income substitution, 
where required 
•  Environmental risks identification and arrangements for environmental 
management and monitoring 
 
Institutional framework  •  Main tasks and responsibilities in planning, negotiating, consulting, 
approving, coordinating, implementing, financing, monitoring and 
evaluating land acquisition and resettlement  
•  Review of mandate of the land acquisition and resettlement agencies and 
their capacity to plan and manage these tasks  
•  Provision for capacity building, including technical assistance, if required.  
•  Role of NGOs, if involved, and organizations of affected persons in 
resettlement planning and management 
•  Involvement of women’s groups in resettlement planning, management 
and operations, job creation and income generation  
•  Female staff should be hired by the resettlement agency to work with and 
assist women in all aspects of resettlement activities, including planning 
and implementation of income restoration programs 
 
Resettlement budget and  •  Cost estimates, budgets and cash flows for meeting the objectives of the 
financing  resettlement plan according to established schedules 
•  Land acquisition and resettlement costs  
•  Annual budget and timing for release of funds.  
•  Sources of funding for all land acquisition and resettlement activities 
 
Implementation schedule  •  Time schedule showing start and finish dates for major resettlement tasks  
•  Time bound actions for projected activities to ensure that people affected 
are compensated and assisted before award of civil works contracts or 
similar milestone, ensuring as a minimum that affected people will be 
provided with entitlements, such as land and asset compensation and 
transfer allowances, prior to their displacement 
 
Monitoring and  •  Plan for internal monitoring of resettlement targets, specifying key 
evaluation  indicators of progress, mechanisms for reporting, resource requirements 
and database maintenance.  
•  Plan for external and independent monitoring and evaluation   
•  Participation of affected people in monitoring and evaluation 
•  Impacts on women
